Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative for Capacity Building-Preparing STEM Teachers for Alaska

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
With capacity-building funds from the NSF Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship Program, partners from the University of Alaska Southeast School of Education (UAS-SOE), the University of Alaska Fairbanks School of Education (UAF-SOE), the University of Alaska Anchorage College of Education (UAA-COE), the University of Alaska Fairbanks College of Natural Science & Mathematics (CNSM), in collaboration with the Yukon Koyukuk School District (YKSD) and Nenana School District (high- need local Education Agency (LEA) will establish the infrastructure and collaborations that will lead to increasing the number and diversity of highly-qualified mathematics and science teachers in high-need and rural schools across Alaska. The State of Alaska has a particularly large number of very small rural schools that often have only one teacher who is responsible for all STEM subjects and across grade levels. In addition, Alaska has one of the lowest high school graduation rates and one of the lowest college-going rates. This project will serve as a catalyst and opening doors to new, sustainable partnerships and ideas in the collaborative pursuit of increasing the number and diversity of effective mathematics and science teachers who are prepared to teach in rural villages and Alaska Native communities.

Project partners will develop a long-term plan for increasing the number of mathematics and science teachers who are prepared to integrate crosscutting STEM concepts in the curriculum to engage student learning. Specifically, project partners will (1) develop relationships for a collaborative approach to recruiting and preparing secondary STEM teacher candidates; (2) collect baseline data to determine interest, need, and capacity, as well as study successful practices from current Noyce projects; (3) explore effective program structures and timelines for future pre-service teachers while utilizing mathematics and science major university programs for the development of a modern, flexible, and effective pathway toward a math/science teacher licensure; (4) design a framework for a multilayered, sustainable recruitment program focusing on diversity participation (Alaska Natives) in teaching of STEM; and (5) establish collaborative structures with Alaska high-need local educational agencies (LEAs) to facilitate teaching experiences, employment, and mentor training. The project will develop a model that can be adapted for other rural contexts, while reflecting the needs of stakeholders in Alaska.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Collaborative for Capacity Building -preparing STEM Teachers for Alaska

The Robert Noyce grant planning project explored and established infrastructure and partnerships for implementing a Robert Noyce Scholarship Program in Alaska to increase the number and diversity of math and science teachers, enabling them to integrate crosscutting STEM concepts in the curriculum to engage student learning in high-needs school districts with Alaska Native (AN) students.

During the duration of the project university leaders of the University of Alaska campuses that have teacher education programs: the University of Alaska Anchorage (UAA), the University of Alaska Fairbanks (UAF), the University of Alaska Southeast (UAS), and the UAF College of Natural Sciences and Mathematics met with school district and indigenous community leaders to collect base line data to determine interest, need, and place-relevant student teacher training opportunities in rural Alaska.

The project was successful in establishing the demand for more STEM teachers with crosscutting subject area knowledge especially in rural Alaska by surveying and interviewing school district administrators, teachers and student teachers. Results included the demand for funded student teaching in rural schools, better cultural induction, special training to increase knowledge in place-relevant crosscutting STEM methodology and trauma- informed classroom management skills. Focused partnerships were established with four Alaskan rural school districts (Alaska Gateway School District, Nenana City School District, Nome-Northwestern Alaska Career and Technical Center, Yukon-Koyukuk School District), who are interested and committed to actively support STEM teacher training and field-based teacher practice in their rural schools. Those partnerships are functional and will be expanded and supported by a future Robert Noyce Scholarship Program.

An unexpected state-wide financial crisis in Alaska in 2019 and leadership instability at the University of Alaska hampered collaboration for a future Robert Noyce Scholarship Program. Despite the cautionary assessment of fiscal and leadership stability needs, this project was a catalyst for developing sustainable partnerships across the University of Alaska campuses UAF and UAS and high-needs LEA school districts to foster ideas in the collaborative pursuit of increasing the number and diversity of effective STEM teachers in Alaska, who are prepared to teach in rural villages and Alaska Native communities. The project demonstrated that stable leadership commitments at all levels, workable university and state budgets, and a vision for education as investment in the future of the state and country are needed to implement programs, which attract and support talented and diverse students.

In summary, the project established that the Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship Program can provide much needed financial support for Alaska’s STEM teacher candidates and recruitment process to increase minority participation in the teacher profession. Spirited risk-taking, committed leadership at the university and sustainable stakeholder support are also needed for a Robert Noyce Scholarship Program implementation promoting necessary change in STEM teacher education in Alaska and will be addressed in a future full proposal.
